data.title: 19 Best Netflix Games to Play on Netflix Right Now - Netflix Tudum
data.meta_description: Wondering what games you can play on Netflix? From Oxenfree and Kentucky Route Zero to Heads Up!, there’s an entire library waiting.
data.text:
You already know about the vast collection of TV shows and movies you can watch on Netflix, but you might not know that there’s an entire other library you can access with your subscription: an ever-growing collection of mobile games to play directly on your devices.

Whether you’re looking for quick distractions to play in two-minute bursts or engrossing narrative experiences that will keep you occupied for hours, there’s a game for you. Some are brand new, while others are classics waiting to be revisited.

You can always peruse Netflix’s entire collection of games by scrolling through their designated row in the mobile app. But if you want recommendations, you’ve come to the right place. Here are 19 games that subscribers can — and should — play right now.

The Queen’s Gambit Chess

Have visions of chess pieces danced in your head (or on your ceiling) since you watched Beth Harmon play her way through The Queen’s Gambit? Starting this summer, you can reenter Beth’s world and take lessons, play puzzles and matches, and compete against friends in The Queen’s Gambit Chess. Beyond the chessboard, players will get to see locations like Beth’s house, the Methuen orphanage and the Las Vegas tournament, and Beth herself will offer up tips and challenges. Whether you’re a chess newbie or an experienced champion, the game is sure to capture your attention — all you have to do is make that first move. (Available July 25 on Apple and Android.)

Stranger Things: Puzzle Tales

If you like solving puzzles as much as Eddie Munson likes shredding on his guitar, this is the game for you. Stranger Things: Puzzle Tales is a match-3 RPG that lets players form their own Hawkins dream team with characters like Eleven and Hopper, and use them to take on baddies like the Demogorgon and the Mind Flayer. Game modes include puzzles and missions that allow you to explore the Upside Down, all with a roster of more than 30 playable characters including aforementioned fan-favorite Munson — and now players can test their strengths by taking on Stranger Things’ ultimate villain: Vecna. Have your favorite song at the ready, just in case. (Play on Apple or Android.)

Too Hot to Handle: Love Is a Game

As the title suggests, Too Hot to Handle: Love Is a Game is a tie-in game for the reality series of the same name, in which a group of gorgeous singles is trapped in a tropical paradise together with a large sum of cash up for grabs — as long as they can resist hooking up with one another. The game features all the trappings of the show, from the fan-favorite rule-enforcing virtual assistant Lana to the diverse cast of hotties.

You may know the gimmick already — that the contestants aren’t allowed to so much as kiss without losing money — but the characters in the game are blissfully unaware at the beginning. The game’s sequel (which is coming soon) levels up on the action, introducing Season 1’s Chloe Veitch as an in-game love guru and giving even more ways to customize your avatar, from astrology signs to new interests (think Animal Lover, Foodie, Fashionista, Gamer, etc) to see how much your character vibes with others. (Play on Apple or Android.)

Kentucky Route Zero

Cardboard Computer and Annapurna Interactive’s now-classic adventure game is officially billed as “a magical realist adventure game about a secret highway running through the caves beneath Kentucky, and the mysterious folks who travel it.” It was released as five distinct chapters between 2013 and 2020, when it was finally finished. Now, it’s available on mobile for the first time.

The game itself is hard to describe; it’s a dark trip through surreal rabbit holes that will tickle your imagination with well written poetry and prose. The gameplay isn’t exactly traditional, but anyone who’s played a classic adventure game will feel at home. If you’re looking for something artistic and inventive, Kentucky Route Zero is the game for you. (Play on Apple or Android.)

Twelve Minutes

Simple gameplay that anyone can enjoy? Check. Mysterious time loop that will make you desperate to know what’s going on? You bet. Exciting cast of talented actors to flesh out the world and breathe life into the characters? Oh yeah. We’re talking about Twelve Minutes, a narrative thriller featuring James McAvoy, Daisy Ridley and Willem Dafoe.

Developed by Luis Antonio and published by Annapurna Interactive, Twelve Minutes takes place in the apartment of a man who arrives home one stormy evening to have a quiet night with his wife, only to be interrupted by an unsavory visitor. When things really start to go wrong, the loop resets –– leaving you wondering what you can possibly do to avoid a normal evening turning into the worst night of your life. (Play on Apple or Android.)

Poinpy

Poinpy is the perfect kind of phone game. Designed from the ground up for touch screens, it requires nothing more than dragging your finger along the screen. But from that simple mechanism comes a deeply satisfying adventure that will have you instantly addicted.

Poinpy was designed by Ojiro Fumoto, whose previous mobile game, Downwell, sent players hurtling down through increasingly dangerous shafts filled with enemies and obstacles. This game turns that concept on its head, tasking you with bouncing upwards as you collect increasingly complex combinations of fruit to satiate the giant green monster chasing you from below. It’s adorable, satisfying and ultimately irresistible. (Play on Apple or Android.)

Immortality

Designer Sam Barlow made a name for himself with 2015’s Her Story, a unique game that told an interactive story using live-action footage of a fictional police interrogation. Immortality is equally experimental, similarly taking advantage of live-action videos, with a captivating performance from actor Manon Gage.

The game concerns a fictional actor, Marissa Marcel, whose disappearance has never been solved. By investigating clips from her films and behind-the-scenes footage, you can uncover shocking twists. The unusual gameplay style might not be conventional, but it’s a perfect fit for your phone. (Play on Apple or Android.)

Oxenfree

If you haven’t played Oxenfree yet, stop what you’re doing and go download it now. Night School Studio’s flagship game is a lovingly crafted narrative adventure that has been capturing players’ hearts since its original release in 2016 — and now it’s available as part of Netflix’s gaming roster.

The game is an old-school supernatural thriller with horror-lite elements (more Scooby-Doo than The Babadook). You control Alex, a teenager who visits a creepy island with a group of friends. They explore the island and chat with one another as a mystery gradually unfolds. Oxenfree won awards for its excellent story and presentation, and once you play it, you’ll quickly see why. (Play on Apple or Android.)

Desta: The Memories Between

Few games are as good-looking as Ustwo Games’ Monument Valley series, which nestled perfectly on phone screens with trippy, colorful visuals and M.C. Escher-inspired perspective puzzles. For the studio’s latest game, Desta, they went in a very different direction, but the results are equally arresting.

You play as Desta, a heartbroken young girl whose dreams are filled with metaphorically-charged dodgeball games featuring figures from her past. Yes, you read that correctly. The emotional narrative takes shape gradually as you chuck rubber balls at former teachers and other characters, while managing teammates and opponents with a variety of skills and strengths. Desta is unlike anything else we’ve played. (Play on Apple or Android.)

Into the Breach

Into the Breach is one of the most beloved puzzle games of recent years, scratching the major itch that strategy enthusiasts start to feel if they haven’t done any chess-like calculations for several minutes.

The game sees you directing futuristic mech combatants on grid-shaped battlefields in turn-based bouts that range from a few minutes to much longer. The gameplay is simple, with a handful of movement and attack options per turn. But the depth is unending, with strategies inside strategies thanks to varied battlefields and a huge array of unlockable mechs with different skills and powers. If strategy is your thing, Into the Breach is the perfectly addictive bite-sized puzzle for you. (Play on Apple or Android.)

Wonderputt Forever

Designer Reece Millidge’s Wonderputt Forever sends you down the rabbit hole-in-one through shockingly inventive mini-golf courses. This isn’t your average goofball mini-putt; we're talking about flying golf balls navigating through eons of human history, futuristic zoos and quantum micro-universes inside nuclear explosions.

These courses are divided into deliciously bite-sized chapters, so whether you want to be wowed for days or simply have your faculties occupied for 10 seconds while waiting in line somewhere, Wonderputt Forever is a truly wonderful mobile game. (Play on Apple or Android.)

Moonlighter

Plenty of games have you delve into increasingly challenging dungeons while scrounging for supplies and treasures. Usually you return back to the surface to sell your spoils to the nearest shop, exchanging stuff for gold so you can buy better gear. But what if you ran the shop as well? That’s the concept of Moonlighter, an adorable and absorbing role-playing game from Spanish indie studio Digital Sun.

Mysterious, ever-changing dungeons lie in wait just outside your hometown, where your family has run the Moonlighter shop for generations. The dungeons' deeper levels are closed to most, but you aren’t the average adventurer. Combat is beautifully simple, fine-tuned for touchscreen controls, and managing the town’s economy during the day by strategically lowering and raising prices is surprisingly satisfying. (Play on Apple or Android.)

Heads Up!

Heads Up! is a classic party game, a cousin of charades in which the other players have to help you guess the word you’re holding up to your forehead. But in this case, the chaotic fun is all housed in your phone.

On top of that, the Netflix edition of the game is filled with trivia, so the family that watches together will win together, too. Categories include beloved shows like Squid Game, Bridgerton and Stranger Things, not to mention genres, movies and more. Just make sure to cover any mirrors in the room to prevent cheating. (Play on Apple or Android.)

Lucky Luna

Some games hit the exact right combination of graphics, gameplay and story. For mobile games, you tend to want those things to be as intuitive and accessible as possible. That’s what makes Lucky Luna so great. The classic-inspired pixel art is sure to spark some nostalgia, while the rewarding gameplay involves simple finger-swiping controls.

The game concerns Luna, a young girl navigating mysterious temples and ruins inspired by Japanese folklore. You’ll be hooked by its beautiful visuals, and eventually discover a surprisingly deep experience. (Play on Apple or Android.)

Before Your Eyes

Some of the best phone games fit right at home on mobile devices by using features that are only possible on smartphones. GoodbyeWorld Games and publisher Skybound Games have created something truly unique with Before Your Eyes, which takes advantage of a feature seldom seen in games: eye-tracking via your phone’s front-facing selfie camera.

The game casts you as a recently deceased person named Benjamin Brynn, who gets to explore the memories of his life on his way to the afterlife. The eye-tracking tech can sense where you’re looking and even when you blink, creating immersive and unique mechanics and controls. (Play on Apple or Android.)

Scriptic: Crime Stories

The team behind Scriptic describes the series as “a mobile platform for immersive, deep interactive, live-action stories” that even uses generative AI to help tell them. What that translates to, in this case, is a neat narrative adventure in which you play as a detective using technology to investigate a crime scene.

You’ll go through the victim’s phone, check their messages, interrogate witnesses and coordinate with others in the investigative force to get to the bottom of the mystery. It’s gritty and has a realistic tone, making it perfect for true crime enthusiasts. (Play on Apple or Android.)

Reigns: Three Kingdoms

Reigns: Three Kingdoms is the latest entry in the Reigns series of strategy games. Unlike most strategy games, though, the Devolver Digital series doesn’t have you moving units around on a battlefield, but instead making the strategic decisions that shape a nation on every level. The original game was released in 2016, and it’s had several sequels and spin-offs, including one based on Game of Thrones.

For Three Kingdoms, the designers turned to Chinese history, drawing inspiration from the 14th-century epic novel The Romance of the Three Kingdoms. The result is a gripping trip through time with gameplay not seen in any other game series. It may seem as simple as swiping left or right, but spend some time in Reigns: Three Kingdoms and you’ll feel like you’re making history. (Play on Apple or Android.)

Valiant Hearts: Coming Home

Valiant Hearts: Coming Home is a combination of survival games, puzzles and World War I history lessons. Players will join the Harlem Hellfighters, the first African American infantry to fight in the war, as they enter the battlefield and learn about these unsung heroes.

Developed by Ubisoft, Valiant Hearts: Coming Home is a sequel to Valiant Hearts: The Great War. “Despite being one of the most highly decorated regiments at the time, these soldiers’ contributions to the war effort went unrecognized for nearly a century after the war ended,” the Ubisoft team recently told Tudum. “They are an inspiring piece of American history, so it was important for us to highlight them in the game.” (Play on Apple or Android.)

Tomb Raider Reloaded

Whether you’re already a fan or a novice to the Tomb Raider series, embark on a brand new adventure in Tomb Raider Reloaded. Lara Croft is back in action, and this time players will help her defeat even more enemies in order to advance through different stages. What can you expect on this quest? Be on the lookout for underground tombs, dangerous mountain caves, hidden traps and even a T. rex.

First launched in 1996, Tomb Raider has spawned several adaptations and spin-offs over the past 27 years. Tomb Raider Reloaded is the latest addition to the franchise. (Play on Apple or Android.)
